GLYCOPYRRONIUM BROMIDE

ANTIMUSCARINICS (SYSTEMIC)ANTIMUSCARINICS (INHALED)

  • Indications and doses
  • Pregnancy
  • Renal impairment
  • Contra indications
  • Side effects
  • Patient and carer advice

  • Cautions
  • Medicinal forms

Indications and doses

Iontophoretic treatment of hyperhidrosis,

To the skin

  • For adults
    Only 1 site to be treated at a time, mximum 2 sites treated in any 24 hours, treatment not to be repeated within 7 days (consult product literature).

Premedication at induction,

By intramuscular injection or by intravenous injection

  • For adults
    200–400 micrograms, alternatively 4–5 micrograms/kg (max. per dose 400 micrograms).

Intra-operative bradycardia,

By intravenous injection

  • For adults
    200–400 micrograms, alternatively 4–5 micrograms/kg (max. per dose 400 micrograms), repeated if necessary.

Control of muscarinic side-effects of neostigmine in reversal of non-depolarising neuromuscular block,

By intravenous injection

  • For adults
    10–15 micrograms/kg, alternatively, 200 micrograms per 1 mg of neostigmine to be administered.

Bowel colic in palliative care, Excessive respiratory secretions in palliative care,

By subcutaneous infusion

  • For adults
    200 micrograms every 4 hours and when required, hourly use is occasionally necessary, particularly in excessive respiratory secretions.
  • For adults
    0.6–1.2 mg/24 hours.

Maintenance treatment of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease,

By inhalation of powder

  • For adults
    50 micrograms once daily.

Dose equivalence and conversion

For inhalation of powder, each 50 microgram capsule of glycopyrronium delivers 44 micrograms of glycopyrronium.

Advice when patient is pregnant

When used by inhalation

Manufacturer advises use only if potential benefit outweighs risk.

Advice regarding renal impairment

When used by inhalation

Use with caution if eGFR less than 30 mL/minute/1.73 m2.

Contra indications

Known side effects

Specific side effects

commonOrVeryCommon: insomnia,

uncommon: epistaxis, hyperglycaemia, hypoaesthesia, malaise, rhinitis,

notKnown: tingling at administration site,

With topical use

Topical use

The possibility of systemic side-effects should be considered; however; glycopyrrhonium is poorly absorbed and systemic effects unlikely with topical use.

Advice for patients and carers

When used by inhalation

Patients or carers should be given advice on how to administer glycopyrronium for inhalation.

Important safety information

Antimuscarininc drugs used for premedication to general anaesthesia should only be administered by, or under the direct supervision of, personnel experienced in their use.

Cautions regarding administration

  • When used by inhalation: arrhythmia (excluding chronic stable atrial fibrillation)
  • When used by inhalation: history of myocardial infarction
  • When used by inhalation: history of QT-interval prolongation
  • When used by inhalation: left ventricular failure
  • When used by inhalation: unstable ischaemic heart disease
  • With topical use:

    Cautions applicable to systemic use should be considered; however, glycopyrronium is poorly absorbed and systemic effects unlikely with topical use.

Prepared medicinal forms of GLYCOPYRRONIUM BROMIDE

There can be variation in the licensing of different medicines containing the same drug.

Forms available from special-order manufacturers include: oral suspension, oral solution, cream, capsule, ointment, liquid,
Tablet
Solution for injection
Inhalation powder
Powder for solution for iontophoresis
